title: Derby County confirm Gary Rowett as new manager on two-and-a-half-year deal
text:
Rowett's debut will be against Nottingham Forest this weekend (Photo: Nathan Stirk) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Derby County have confirmed the appointment of Gary Rowett as the club's new first-team manager. 
The former Birmingham City boss takes charge of the Rams following Steve McClaren's dismissal at the weekend. 
Rowett, unceremoniously dismissed by Birmingham earlier in the campaign, returns to the East Midlands club, for whom he made over 100 appearances as a player. 
Rowett, 43, has signed a deal at Pride Park until the end of the 2018-19 season and been allowed to make sweeping changes to the club's coaching staff by owner Mel Morris. 
In has come Kevin Summerfield as Assistant Manager, Mark Sale as First Team Coach, Kevin Poole as Goalkeeping Coach and Joe Carnall as Head of Performance Analysis. Rowett will hope to have Derby in the promotion shake-up next season (Photo: Nathan Stirk) 
Their arrivals fill the void created by the departures of assistant manager Chris Powell and technical director Chris Evans, who followed McClaren out the door. 
Kevin Phillips remains as part of the coaching staff as First Team Coach. 
Morris declared: "We are delighted to welcome Gary Rowett back to Derby County as our new manager. 
“Gary is being tasked with, and has the full responsibility for, leading our redevelopment programme. Gary, of course, played for us for three years during his playing career, lives in Derby and is passionate about our football club. 
“He is an exemplar of the qualities and values we want in our team and has clearly demonstrated his abilities to get that from his players too." Rowett had impressed during stints at Birmingham and Burton (Photo: Getty Images) 
Rowett's first match in charge will be the East Midlands derby against rivals Nottingham Forest on Saturday. 
“I’m naturally thrilled to be appointed as the manager of Derby County and can’t wait to get started. 
“I feel that I have a special bond with the club having been here as a player. During that time, we tasted success when we were promoted to the Premier League and moved to Pride Park Stadium under Jim Smith. 
“Living in the local area, I understand the expectation of the fanbase and it goes without saying that Derby County has fantastic and committed supporters. 
“I have coached in the Academy in the past so I know the values of the club and I am looking forward to sharing my experience and knowledge of the league with the staff and players. 
“I am fully aware of the playing squad here and I am looking forward to working with them all first hand.” poll loading Will Gary Rowett be a success at Derby? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
